Fogo API Documentation

This page is a work in progress – signup at fogo.io for updates

Welcome to the Fogo SDK documentation. This page will walk you through everything you need to know to get started developing Apps for Fogo.

Getting Started

First, you need to download and install the following software:

  • Fogo SDK (includes compiler and libraries – coming soon)
  • Fogo Link (desktop application for quickly installing and debugging programs)
  • Eclipse CDT

Anatomy of an App

Fogo Apps are designed based on a state machine (see App). If you have never heard of a state-machine, you might want to read about it on Wikipedia to get a general idea.

A state machine bounces around between states based on certain exit conditions and executes certain actions when entering and leaving each state. For Fogo, we use the AppState class for the state. These methods are used when jumping between states:

  • AppState::entry_action() is executing when entering a state
  • AppState::action() is executing every 20ms while in a state
  • AppState::exit_condition() tests to see if it is time to exit a state

The following methods must pure virtual methods and must be implemented by the inheriting class:

  • AppState::name() returns a pointer to the state's name
  • AppState::draw(MBitmap * bitmap) draws the state on the specified bitmap

In most cases, you will want to re-implement AppState::entry_action() and AppState::action(). The default behavior for these functions is:

  • AppState::entry_action() animates the transition to the state and waits for all buttons to be released
  • AppState::action() turns the light on/off based on a press of the top button
